DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS ARP FUNDED GRANT AGREEMENT IS TO USE THE AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN (ARP) GRANT FUNDING TO CREATE A FUNCTIONING COMMUNITY GARDEN FOR LOW-INCOME SENIORS, NEIGHBORS, AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS IN NEW HAVEN, CONNECTICUT BY THE TOWERS FOUNDATION. THE PRODUCTIVE GREEN SPACE WILL INCLUDE A COMMUNITY GARDEN AND TEACHING SPACE FOR TOWERS' LOW-INCOME SENIOR CITIZEN RESIDENTS. THE GREEN SPACE WILL IMPROVE AIR QUALITY AND REDUCE THE NEED FOR BUSES TO TRANSPORT PEOPLE TO THE GROCERY STORE FOR FRESH PRODUCE. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO IMPROVE LOCAL RESIDENT AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF LOCAL ENVIRONMENT AND PUBLIC HEALTH CONDITIONS RELATED TO LOCAL AMBIENT AIR QUALITY. THIS PROJECT CAN BE FUNDED UNDER SECTION 103(B) OF THE CLEAN AIR ACT (CAA). THE TOWERS FOUNDATION IS THE SUPPORTING ORGANIZATION TO THE TOWERS AT TOWER LANE, THE MAIN HOME FOR GREATER NEW HAVEN'S LOW INCOME ELDERLY AND MINORITY POPULATION SERVICING OVER 300 LOW INCOME, DIVERSE SENIORS. THE TOWERS IS SURROUNDED BY I-95 AND I-91 PUTTING IT IN VERY CLOSE PROXIMITY TO TRAFFIC AND THE PROJECT'S OBJECTIVE IS TO PROVIDE ENVIRONMENTAL AND NUTRITIONAL ASSETS THAT WILL LEAD TO HIGHER QUALITY OF LIFE AND STRONGER COMMUNITY HEALTH. CAA 103(B)(3): PEOPLE WITH MODERATE-TO-SEVERE OR UNCONTROLLED ASTHMA ARE MORE LIKELY TO BE HOSPITALIZED FROM COVID-19. AIR POLLUTION MAY CONTRIBUTE TO ASTHMA. BY ADDRESSING AIR POLLUTION IN CAA 103(B)(3) PROJECTS, THE CHANCES OF SEVERE ILLNESS FROM COVID-19 ARE REDUCED.
ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE: ASSEMBLE A TASK FORCE OF 12 RESIDENTS, PLAN AND DESIGN A NEW GREEN SPACE WITH GARDEN AND LEARNING SPACES, CREATE SIX RAISED BEDS, GENERATE LOCAL GARDEN PRODUCE, REACH OVER 300 RESIDENTS TO RAISE AWARENESS ON ENVIRONMENTAL AND PUBLIC HEALTH ISSUES INCLUDING BENEFITS OF GREEN SPACE AND SELECTING HEALTHY FOOD CHOICES AND IMPROVEMENTS IN AMBIENT AIR QUALITY. THE PROJECT WILL TRACK THE AMOUNT OF HARVEST PRODUCED, GREEN SPACE INCREASED AND CONDUCT FOUR EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE AN INCREASED QUALITY OF LIFE AND COMMUNITY HEALTH THROUGH:  1. IMPROVED AIR QUALITY AND GREEN SPACE FROM ADDED TREES, PLANTS, AND SHADE; 2. REDUCED FOOD INSECURITY RESULTING FROM THE INCREASE OF LOCAL, HEALTHY PRODUCE; 3. INCREASED NUTRITIONAL HEALTH FROM CONSUMING LOCAL FRESH PRODUCE THROUGH NEW GARDENS; 4. EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS TO LEARN MORE ABOUT LOCAL ENVIRONMENT AND PUBLIC HEALTH ISSUES INCLUDING AMBIENT AIR QUALITY; AND 5. EXPANDED SOCIALIZATION AND IMPROVED QUALITY OF LIFE THROUGH ENVIRONMENTAL AND PUBLIC HEALTH ACTIVITIES WITH OTHER RESIDENTS, FAMILIES, FRIENDS, AND NEIGHBORS. INTENDED AND DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE LOW-INCOME SENIOR CITIZENS, NEIGHBORS AND COMMUNITY RESIDENTS IN NEW HAVEN, CONNECTICUT.

DESCRIPTION:
THE PURPOSE OF THIS ARP FUNDED GRANT AGREEMENT IS TO HELP THE TRIBE PLANS INVITE STUDENTS TO ITS 220-ACRE RESERVATION IN NORTH STONINGTON, CT TO LEARN ABOUT AND PARTICIPATE IN THE COMMUNITY GARDEN, PARTICIPATE IN AIR AND WATER QUALITY TESTING AND RECEIVE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION. EASTERN PEQUOT TRIBAL NATION IS A STATE RECOGNIZED TRIBAL GOVERNMENT LOCATED IN CONNECTICUT THAT PLANS TO EXPAND A NATIVE FARM TO SCHOOL PROGRAM THAT PROMOTES HEALTHY EATING, GROWING TECHNIQUES AND TRADITIONAL NATIVE CROPS AT SCHOOLS, AND ON ITS RESERVATION AT THE MARY MOMOHO COMMUNITY GARDEN FOR CHILDREN AND ADULTS. THE COMMUNITY GARDEN SUPPORTS A LONG- STANDING FOOD PANTRY PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES HEALTHY FOOD BUNDLES FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS AND OTHER INDIVIDUALS IN NEED OF ASSISTANCE. THE PROJECT SEEKS TO EXPAND THE TRIBE'S FOOD PANTRY EFFORT BY EXPANDING THE GARDEN TO CARRY OUT THE PROJECT, YIELD MORE CROPS, WATER COLLECTION AND IRRIGATION, OUTFIT A COMPLETE SOLAR GREEN ENERGY SYSTEM FOR THE PROCESSING STATION, EDUCATIONAL ENVIRONMENT, AND ZERO CARBON FOOTPRINT COMMUNITY CENTER. 
ACTIVITIES:
ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED WILL INCLUDE EXPANDING THE COMMUNITY GARDEN BY ADDING MORE RAISED BEDS, PROVIDING MORE FOOD BOXES DISTRIBUTED TO TRIBAL MEMBERS THROUGH THE FOOD PANTRY PROGRAM, CREATING A SUSTAINABLE COMMUNITY SPACE WITH OFF-THE-GRID SOLAR ELECTRIC TECHNOLOGY, INSTALLING SOLAR PANELS AND BATTERY STORAGE, TESTING AIR QUALITY AND WELL WATER QUALITY, CONDUCTING THE NATIVE FARM TO SCHOOL PROGRAM AND THE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM FOR CHILDREN AND ADULTS, PROVIDING VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON TOURS OF THE RESERVATION, AND IMPLEMENTING THE NATIVE ENVIRONMENTAL JUNIOR RANGER PROGRAM FOR CHILDREN. ALL ACTIVITIES ARE DESIGNED TO HELP TRIBAL MEMBERS BETTER UNDERSTAND POLLUTION ISSUES AND ACHIEVE A MORE SUSTAINABLE WAY OF LIFE WITH BETTER FOOD SECURITY.
OUTCOMES:
THE RECIPIENT WILL EXPAND ITS COMMUNITY GARDEN BY INSTALLING 10 RAISED BEDS, INCREASE FOOD ACCESS 3-FOLD OVER TWO YEARS THOUGH TRIBAL FOOD PANTRY PROGRAM, INCREASED ACCESS TO FRESH HEALTHY FOODS, REDUCE TRIBAL CARBON FOOTPRINT, INSTALL SOLAR POWER SYSTEM AT COMMUNITY CENTER FACILITY, TEACH 300 CHILDREN AND ADULTS ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AND SUSTAINABILITY. DELIVERABLES WILL ALSO INCLUDE SEMIANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS TO THE EPA. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES WILL INCLUDE TRIBAL MEMBERS - APPROXIMATELY 300 CHILDREN AND ADULTS - WHO WILL GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTAND OF POLLUTION ISSUES AND ACHIEVE A MORE SUSTAINABLE WAY OF LIFE WITH BETTER FOOD SECURITY.
SUBRECIPIENT:
NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.

PER YOUR APPLICATION REQUEST DATED AUGUST 3, 2017, THIS GRANT AGREEMENT AWARDS FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000 TO THE NEW HAVEN URBAN RESOURCES INITIATIVE'S (NHURI) GREENSKILLS PROGRAM  THAT WILL ADDRESS LOCAL AIR AND WATER QUALITY ISSUES IN NEW HAVEN THROUGH AN INTEGRATED STRATEGY OF MAINTAINING BIOSWALES, PLANTING STREET TREES, AND STEWARDING COMMUNITY PARKS.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO INCREASE AWARENESS ABOUT LEAD SAFETY AND DECREASE THE INCIDENCE OF LEAD POISONING AMONG REFUGEES IN PROVIDENCE, RHODE ISLAND.  PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE HOSTING A SERIES OF CULTURALLY ATTUNED PREVENTATIVE HEALTH EDUCATIONAL SESSIONS THAT WILL PROVIDE PARTICIPANTS AND THEIR FAMILIES THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND RESOURCES ON HOUSING SAFETY AND LEAD POISONING.

SOUTHSIDE COMMUNITY LAND TRUST PLANS TO SUPPORT COMMUNITY BASED EDUCATION ON THE HAZARDS OF TOXIC CONTAMINANTS IN OUR OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENT, AND HOW TO WORK AROUND THOSE HAZARDS TO SAFELY GROW FOOD. IN ADDITION, COMMUNITIES WILL DEVELOP APPROACHES THAT SERVE TO MINIMIZE THE SPREAD OF TOXIC CONTAMINANTS INTO OUR PUBLIC WATERWAYS. RESIDENTS OF ALL AGES WILL LEARN TO COLLECT SAMPLES OF SOILS AND FOODS FOR ACCURATE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS AND THE RESULTS WILL BE SHARED WITH THE GARDENERS AND STUDENTS WORKING IN THESE URBAN GROWING SPACES. RESIDENTS WILL LEARN METHODS FOR CREATING GROWING SYSTEMS THAT AVOID CONTAMINATED SOILS, INCLUDING CREATING IMPERMEABLE BARRIERS AND RAISED GARDEN BEDS. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, OVER 300 LOCAL RESIDENTS WILL BE EMPOWERED TO SAFELY GROW FOOD, AND TO PROTECT THEIR LOCAL ENVIRONMENTS.

THE LEAD-SAFE BLACKSTONE VALLEY INITIATIVE WILL WORK IN THREE OF RHODE ISLAND'S HIGH RISK COMMUNITIES TO REDUCE THE INCIDENCE OF CHILDHOOD LEAD POISONING, IMPROVE THE SAFETY OF RENTAL HOUSING, AND INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF CENTRAL FALLS, PAWTUCKET, AND WOONSOCKET RESIDENTS TO ADDRESS LEAD ISSUES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PROMOTING EFFECTIVE LEAD PREVENTION PRACTICES, DEVELOPING LEAD 101 AND WORKER SAFETY TRAININGS, AND PROVIDING TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. THESE CITIES HAVE A VERY HIGH INCIDENCE OF LEAD POISONING AND ARE HOME TO SUBSTANTIAL LOW-INCOME/MINORITY POPULATIONS.

CENTRAL FALLS, RI SUFFERS FROM LOCALIZED FLOODING ALONG WITH LITTLE GREENSPACE AND TREE COVER. TO ADDRESS THIS, GROUNDWORK RHODE ISLAND (GWRI) PROPOSES TO WORK CLOSELY WITH CENTRAL FALLS HIGH SCHOOL TO DEVELOP A YOUTH-BASED ENVIRONMENTAL PROGRAM FOCUSED ON STORMWATER MANAGEMENT, GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE, PUBLIC GREEN SPACE, TREES, AND SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL. STUDENTS WILL RECEIVE TRAINING FROM A LANDSCAPE ARCHITECT, URBAN PLANNER, AND RELATED PROFESSIONALS ON DESIGN, MASTER PLANNING, AND URBAN SUSTAINABILITY. STUDENTS WILL CONDUCT OUTREACH TO CENTRAL FALLS RESIDENTS AND, BASED ON COMMUNITY INPUT, WILL DESIGN A COMMUNITY GREENING PLAN TO INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THREE GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS.

THE HOUSATONIC VALLEY ASSOCIATION'S (HVAI) STILL RIVER WATERSHED CONNECTIONS PROGRAM ENGAGES DANBURY, CT YOUTH IN THE RESTORATION OF THE STILL RIVER IN ORDER TO BUILD A SENSE OF STEWARDSHIP, TEACH VALUABLE CAREER SKILLS AND PROVIDE A STEADY SOURCE OF VOLUNTEERS FOR WATERSHED RESTORATION PROJECTS. EPA FUNDING WILL SUPPORT SIGNIFICANT EXPANSION OF THE CONNECTIONS PROGRAM TO REACH TWO HUNDRED FIFTY ADDITIONAL AT-RISK YOUTH EACH YEAR.  STUDENTS WILL WORK ON YEAR LONG STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS AND THEN MAKE A PRESENTATION AT AN END-OF-YEAR SYMPOSIUM. HVAI IN PARTNERSHIP WITH DANBURY YOUTH SERVICES (DYS) WILL PROVIDE PAID SUMMER INTERNSHIP EXPERIENCES WORKING ON RIVER RESTORATION PROJECTS TO AQUATIC SCIENCE STUDENT ALUMNI. WITH SUPPORT FROM HVAI IN PARTNERSHIP WITH DANBURY PUBLIC SCHOOLS, WESTERN CONNECTICUT STATE UNIVERSITY AND OTHER LOCAL PARTNERS, AQUATIC SCIENCE STUDENTS AND TEACHERS WILL DEVELOP SOLUTIONS TO REAL-WORLD POLLUTION PROBLEMS IDENTIFIED IN THE STILL RIVER WATERSHED PLAN.
